samples.raw_sample: control it. In time, she would succeed, just as David had. She was glad that he had gone off early this morning. He disliked to hear the children bickering, and it was important that he should not be worried today. If this deal didn't go through. She tried to shake off the sudden despondency, remembering all the unexpected expenses; the need for a new motor scythe, and the re- 361 MAY 1965 pair bill for the station wagon, the strain on David's face, after an evening spent in worried calculations. There were bills that must be settled by the end of the month, and it was the 20th, already. The 20th! The hand slicing bread tensed and stopped. Unseeingly, she stared through the window at the lovely, sunlit garden. It was their wedding anniversary. And they had both forgotten all about it! ""'Mum—remember that pattern I bought last week? It's so simple that if you didn't mind slipping out to buy that blue silk I showed you in Cooper's window, you could make a frock by tomorrow." Celia spoke pleadingly, one slim hand on the doorknob. 'You know how quick you are!"' "And you know how busy she is," countered young Bob, munching steadily through his bowl of cereal. "You ought to make your own dress, Cil."' JEFF laughed. "You might as well ask her to cook her own meals." "Boys — boys!" Mrs. Roberts prayed for the inward peace so necessary to manage this temperamental family of hers. 'Be fair to your sister. She works hard in the garden, and does her share when it comes to redecorating." "But those are men's jobs." Jeff sounded quite concerned. "How will she manage, when she marries?" This time Celia could not restrain her annoyance. 'No wonder Lucy had a quarrel with you. She's better off, if you ask me." "T didn't ask you!" Jeff's reply was ominously quiet. 362 They were at it again. Mrs. Roberts ran a hand over her forehead. "Celia, you'll miss your train. If I get that material and make the frock, you'll have to pay for it."' Celia had been overspending since she had become friendly with Brian. If only she could come to realize that Philip, her old boy friend, was the one for her. He had such a steadying influence, and Celia needed someone like that. "Bless you, Mummy dear—and thanks."" Temper was forgotten as quickly as it had arisen. "I'll pay you back—with interest." She waved a grateful hand. "Bye now!" Then she was gone—a whirl of navy skirt, lemon sweater, and bronze fall of bobbing hair, with a crimson and orange daubed canvas beneath one arm. "You know what?" asked Bob, eating egg and bacon with enthusiasm, "Cil will end up as one of those artists who live in a garret, with a candle and no food." "Not on your life!" Jeff stood up, a tall, dark boy, with an attractive smile. "'She's got enough sense to stay at home and let Mum look after her." He looked tired. He had been brooding about that break with Lucy. A pity! She was a sweet girl. Mi rs. Roberts inspected her firstborn with the wistful glance of a mother, who, powerless to help, has to watc

samples.raw_sample: verdancy which surrounds us is breathtaking. The luxuriant New Zealand fern, bushland, and wild flowers with their coats of many colors are indeed something to behold. On South Island, we find New Zealand's highest mountain, Mount Cook. It towers above the long chain of the Southern Alps, its peaks reaching upward toward the azure sky as high as 12,349 feet. Surrounding them is Mount Cook National Park which covers an area of 173,000 acres. Approximately one-third of this great park is covered with permanent snow and_ glaciers. We have watched these glaciers spilling downward from great heights, with cracks and crevasses opening and closing. They slowly move forward at times as much as two feet a day. Let's wave our magic wand now and view something entirely different in nature. The Hastings area is often referred to as the "Orchard Garden Center' of New Zealand. When we visit in the homes in this city, fresh fruit is served with all meals and at tea time (mid-morning and mid-afternoon). The apples, pears, raspberries, and potatoes are most delicious, and our dear Maori friends supply our needs wherever we are in New Zealand. The fruit yield from this area is approximately two and a quarter million bushels of first grade fruit per season and more is being produced annually. A never-to-be-forgotten sight is to witness the fruit orchards in full bloom. This is indeed a glimpse of quiet beauty and a New Zealand�A Silhouette in Green perfume not yet perfected in bottles. The flower arrangements in hotels and in the homes are beyond description, pleasing to the eye. We were motoring through New Zealand not long ago with some of our American friends interested in re-forestration. We were certainly in the right place, for the largest manmade forest in the world is found in this small country. It covers 284,000 acres. Our friends were also interested in farming, livestock, freezing works, and wool production. We drove through the countryside, along the river edge, low hills and higher slopes, feasting our eyes on the green paddocks enclosed with hedgerows where sheep and cattle were peacefully grazing. We saw wild flowers in full bloom, the pohutukawa (New Zealand's Christmas tree) dressed in its profusion of red flowers, white mountain lilies, pines, and bushlands. We discussed the fact that New Zealand produces over one-tenth of all the wool in the world, that fifty per cent of the mutton and beef produced is exported, as well as ninety-three per cent of the lamb, so one can see that it is plentiful. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has been mindful of New Zealand and its people for many, many years, for it was in 1854 that the first missionaries were sent out from Church headquarters to that faraway land. In 1880, or twenty-six years later, the elders were assigned to go out into the villages and there organize and conduct classes in schools that the children might receive an education. This assignment was carried out until the 191 Marc

samples.raw_sample: home. I hoped you could see the gracious living it offers, under the dust and neglect of these past few years." "You admitted yourself it's too out-of-date. I am anxious to make a home for you, but there are limitations to what I can do " How 40 can I tell you I'm frightened at the prospect of living here with your grandfather and your brother? I don't know anything about handicapped children. I'm afraid to even attempt to rear Davy. What if I failed in some way? Oh, Dick, I knew all these things before we were married, and I accepted them all without question. I was so in love! Can anyone, particularly a girl in love, visualize such things? I didn't see a day past that beautiful ceremony in the London temple and the honeymoon that followed. Now the magnitude of it all frightens me. I am such a coward. This house and everything that goes with it are just overwhelming! \ E can't live in it as it ls now," he said quietly, running a thin hand through his prematurely silver-touched hair. "I can see that. I had hoped to set up my studio in the solarium... Sort of an office... Well, modern plumbing and appliances will make all the difference in the world." "Didn't you hear one word I said?" "T heard you, but we have to be practical. If it won't be too much of a hardship on you, I want to try to live here. I would like to rear our baby here, where I was reared. You have judged the house too quickly, anyway. You haven't seen enough of it. Just starting out in business as I am, I have to think of expenses. It would help a lot to have a place here where I. Could work until I'm established. The money I earned in South Africa won't last forever. It's time we got down to the business of living nor- mal lives, Irene. We've been married seven months. That's a pretty long honeymoon. Besides, you knew about this house... And everything else... A year ago." She couldn't deny that. He hadn't hidden anything from her. 'They had discussed it many times. She had always agreed before. It was hard to veto those prior arrangements now. He left her while he went to explore the rest of the house. Irene stood shivering alone in the kitchen, thinking of the years that Dick's family had lived here. Dick's father, Dick, and Davy had all been born in the same room. Dick's parents had both died here. It was no wonder Dick revered the house. The rooms echoed with reverberations from the past that were foreign to Irene. 'The gloom seemed to close in about her, although it couldn't have been much past the noon hour. 'The sun was high outside. She longed for that sunlight as the eerie quiet enveloped her. She drew her breath in deeply through her mouth, and tasted staleness, dead air, dust. She waited for Dick in the deathlike silence of the old mansion that had waited five years for him to come back and resurrect it. Few short hours ago she had felt like the bride she was, then she had stepped across the threshold of this hideous old house. Everything had changed at that moment. He

samples.raw_sample: large flowers, made of crepe paper or tissue paper, were attached with florist's wire. A few blue-green satin balls were interspersed among the white boughs. Sister Christensen who trimmed this attractive tree formerly lived in Parleys Stake, Salt Lake City, and is now a resident of Frankfurt, Germany. Trimmed by Alice Christensen Displayed at a homemaking exhibit Relief Society Annual General Conference TRANSPARENCIES BY J M. HESLOP 916 Z. C. M. I. AISLE OF CHRISTMAS TREES COURTESY HAROLD H. BENNETT, PRESIDENT TRANSPARENCY BY ) M. HESLOP Poinsettia Tree OO) Soft candlelight and deep red poinsettias make this tree a decorative work of art. The beauty of the Christmas flower and the symbolism of the candlelight bring the radiant Christmas season into a delightfully original portrait of 'a tree with trimmings." Celebrating Christmas Without Going Into Debt Mary E. Bergman () In the early years of our marriage the available money for Christmas expenditures was scarce. After listening to friends expound on the pitfalls of charge accounts that would take months to pay off, lavish gifts to children that seldom pleased them for more than a few weeks, and fancy holiday parties, I realized that it would be most advantageous to fall back on my own resources. Often, the innocence of childhood can be changed into selfishness by parents who are unable to withstand the onslaught of hardsell tactics employed at Christmas time. Our gifts to Cathy that year totaled an expenditure of fifty-nine cents, but required hours of time and preparation. She was delighted, and her enjoyment of our homemade toys led me to believe that I had stumbled on a precious secret. Throughout the years, my children and I have learned together the satisfaction of counters filled with delicious home-baked goodies. Amid the pleasant aromas in our home, we stitched 'God Bless Our Home" samplers, for each adult on our list, and we made stuffed toys of all varieties for the children, and a boxful to be sent to the Primary Children's Hospital. For the entire holiday season, we become absorbed in sewing, gluing, baking, molding salt clay, painting, building, and so on. Mark, being a normal energetic boy, doesn't always adapt to these quiet occupations. One afternoon while Cathy and I were engrossed in a project, I gave Mark a bowl of vegetables to chop for homemade soup that was bubbling on the stove. He was fascinated by the process of putting raw materials into the kettle and afterward being able to savor the taste of the resulting soup. Thereafter he became the official soup maker, starting from scratch and doing the entire project himself. We poured this soup into decorated quart jars to be delivered to various people. TRANSPARENCY BY DOROTHY J. ROBERTS (continued on page 935, with illustrations) 918 | A Thing Of Beauty Is a Joy Candles of Elegance Edythe K. Watson, Member, General Board of Relief Society C0 Relief Society women are ingenious. Show them a thing of beauty and lo! With their

Transparencies by Dorothy J. Roberts (continued on page 935, with illustrations) 918 A Thing of Beauty Is a Joy Candles of Elegance, Edythe K. Watson, Member, General Board of Relief Society Relief Society women are ingenious. Show them a thing of beauty and lo! With their own magic hands they can create its likeness. Since variety is a necessary requisite of any worthy Relief Society project, they change and add, putting a new detail here and color there, enhancing and beautifying most every object. Such it was with the candlesticks made by the sisters of Valley View Eighth Ward, Valley View Stake, under the direction of Sister Janet G. Ogden. Each one was different in color and design, and each was decorated by the sisters to blend and add charm to the decor of the different homes. The tall, more ornate candlesticks were designed for use in the living room or family room areas. The shorter, smaller ones were planned to grace a dining room or kitchen table. A variety of finishes was used. Some were painted with a flat paint and finished with an antique glaze. The smaller ones were covered with enamel paint; the large ringed candles were stained in walnut finish with an antique glaze added. Flowers, fruits, greens, and ribbons were used to decorate them. Some of the sisters made their own candles where a particular color and size was needed. samples.raw_sample: house. His father made the frame from cardboard, and the family decorated it. The gingerbread must be glued to the frame while it is still hot, so that it is soft enough to work with. The house can then be decorated to suit the family. A a te ry Ps ~ F. Ff = i B 4 � " ( Xa * 6 Ae as Blending Colors for Christmas Home of Walter R. And Ardell Ross Artificial fruit, pine cones, and leaves, sprayed gold, and attractively arranged, form the basis for Ardell Ross' Christmas table. The red candles are even more striking when the table is set with red dishes. A dark green, many-branched _ tree, with multi-colored _ lights, stands near the end of the table and sheds a soft light upon the table. An almost feathery effect is created by the use of pink lights on a white tree. Red poinsettias and golden doves contrast and blend with the pink and white. Around Christmas time it seems fitting that we use as decoration in our homes some reminder. Of that joyful occurrence we commemorate at the Christmas season. Anyone can buy beautiful decorations, but how much more meaning will something beautiful you made yourself have to you and your family! Materials needed: 1. Plaster of Paris heads, hands, and feet for Joseph, Mary, and Jesus (these were 3%" high for Joseph, 3" for Mary and 2" for Jesus). They came with matching plaster hands and feet, except for the baby; for him you may use plastic hands. 2. Styrofoam cones, one 21" tall for Joseph, and one 10" tall for Mary (remember she is seated). 3. Cotton fabric and white water solvent glue or cotton pre-treated draping fabric available at craft stores. 4. Wire strong but bendable and a good quality glue. 5. Paint in desired colors, antiquing, and spray glaze. Transparency by J M. Heslop "The Holy Family" Johna de St Jeor Member General Board of Relief Society Plaster heads, hands, and feet come with holes in them. Insert wire pieces, glue, and allow to dry. Stick wires securely into cones forming shoulders, arms, and necks (with head on top) for both Joseph and Mary, but for Mary, shape wire and secure for sitting position. It may be necessary to pad or wrap with fabric shoulders and legs for a more life-like form. Pose the figures' arms and legs to the desired form. Using a picture of the nativity scene, cut the fabric to resemble the type of clothing used in those times. If you are using pre-treated fabric dip and drape; if regular cotton, dilute glue with water and dip fabric and drape on figure; allow to dry completely. Paint whole with several coats of gesso. Refer to picture, using it as a guide for pleasingly rich colors for the clothing. After paint is dry, apply antiquing, being sure to get it back into the folds of fabric. Wipe off the glaze and allow to dry. Spray with clear finish to acquire a shining, clear, china-like surface. More than one coat of spray may be necessary. Use the same technique for the Child. Organize the three figures in a loving family group. 923 Cultural Retin Transparencies by | M

Organize the three figures in a loving family group. 923 Cultural Retin Transparencies by J M. Heslop Relief Society Booth at L.D.S. Open House Utah State Fair September 11-20, 1970 Under a General Board committee, with Edythe K. Watson as chairman, the Olympus Stake Relief Society Board, with the cooperation of Stake President LeGrand Curtis, prepared this beautifully arranged and informative display. The oil paintings by Clyde Smith (of Olympus Stake) represented the courses of study and services of Relief Society: visiting teaching, compassionate service, Singing Mothers, spiritual living, social relations, and cultural refinement. The artist painted the pictures especially for the display at the fair. They are 30 inches by 48 inches, and all the models are from Olympus Stake. Homemaking arts were illustrated and displayed on a long table covered with an attractive deep blue cloth. Seated on the rocker is Lola J. Peterson, President, Olympus Stake Relief Society, demonstrating the making of an afghan. Continuous demonstrations were given which awakened the interest of those who visited the fair and learned more about Relief Society from narrations presented by stake board members and ward Relief Society officers. 925 Homemaking Display at Relief Society Annual General Conference Views of the Homemaking Display held in the Salt Palace, Salt Lake City, Utah, as a part of the 1970 Relief Society Annual General Conference. The center motif was a carousel, with different displays featured around the large hall. The carousel itself was prepared by Emigration Stake under the direction of President Hazel J. Young. Dorotha Smart supervised the construction of the carousel and was assisted in the displays by JaNeanne Webster. Featured around the carousel were items prepared by stakes throughout the Church. The displays included home and gift items, handicraft, foods, pastry and candy, as well as ne items especially designed for children. The nursery display by Modesto Stake, California, under direction of Catherine Openshaw, President, feature

samples.raw_sample: the original library room of the house itself. The school board had rented a truck to go over to Denver and pick up the books from Geniel's home. Also, they had an appropriate sign made to be placed above the front entrance. "You have no idea what this will mean to the children of this town," Geniel remarked to Miss Blayney one afternoon. "Some of them are simply starved for good books." "T think perhaps I do," she replied. "I used to read everything I could get my hands on when I was a child, and it wasn't very much. I always went through the school reader the first week I had it. 'Then I was bored for the rest of the term. I even read old almanacs." Thank goodness, thought Geniel. Otherwise, she wouldn't have been so sympathetic to this cause. By the time she was completely well again, Miss Blayney had_perfected her plans for moving to California. Geniel had rather hoped that she would leave before they took over the rooms for the library, but that was asking too much. Miss Blayney had to oversee operations, help select a librarian, and preside over a formal opening. The mothers of the PTA served punch and cookies, and it was a highly successful affair. "T've never secn Miss Blayney quite so much in her element in all the years I've been here," observed Christine. "In fact, she was having such a good time that I shouldn't be surprised to see her stay on for good." "She is keeping the upstair rooms intact for her lifetime just in case she does get homesick and wants to return. We can't blame her for that. It's sometimes hard for older people to adjust to a new place and way of living," Geniel added. Miss Blayney seemed to be very much afraid of just that but, after considerable hesitation, she finally departed for California to give the new life a try, at least. "Spring was the wrong time for her to leave here,' said Marva dubiously. "But she may just love it down there. We can hope so, at any rate." "Tt really doesn't matter too much if she does come back," said Geniel. "We don't have any use for those upstair rooms so far, anyway. And maybe she'd pay the heating and light bills if she was there." "That's the girl!" cheered Marva. "If there isn't a silver lining, you grab some scraps and make one." Page 533 534 HEY were just sitting down to dinner when Johnny came bursting in without even waiting for anyone to answer his knock. He promptly pulled up a chair and joined them at the table. "Hi, Ellie!" he called. "Bring on an extra plate. This is practically your last chance to have me honor your board." "Your money has come!" said Geniel, beaming. "Good for you!" "Yes, Ma'am." "And now you are leaving for school," added Christine. "No, Ma'am." "You're not!' Marva practically shouted. "Why not? I thought that you had been waiting for this most of your short adult life." "Take it easy, little one,' he countered. "So I have. But something else has come up." "There wasn't as much money in the estate as you had hoped?" Christine suggested quietly. "Wr

I always went through the school reader the first week I had it. 'Then I was bored for the rest of the term. I even read old almanacs." Thank goodness, thought Geniel. Otherwise, she wouldn't have been so sympathetic to this cause. By the time she was completely well again, Miss Blayney had_perfected her plans for moving to California. Geniel had rather hoped that she would leave before they took over the rooms for the library, but that was asking too much. Miss Blayney had to oversee operations, help select a librarian, and preside over a formal opening. The mothers of the PTA served punch and cookies, and it was a highly successful affair. "T've never secn Miss Blayney quite so much in her element in all the years I've been here," observed Christine. "In fact, she was having such a good time that I shouldn't be surprised to see her stay on for good." "She is keeping the upstair rooms intact for her lifetime just in case she does get homesick and wants to return. We can't blame her for that. It's sometimes hard for older people to adjust to a new place and way of living," Geniel added. Miss Blayney seemed to be very much afraid of just that but, after considerable hesitation, she finally departed for California to give the new life a try, at least. "Spring was the wrong time for her to leave here,' said Marva dubiously. "But she may just love it down there. We can hope so, at any rate." "Tt really doesn't matter too much if she does come back," said Geniel. "We don't have any use for those upstair rooms so far, anyway. And maybe she'd pay the heating and light bills if she was there." "That's the girl!" cheered Marva. "If there isn't a silver lining, you grab some scraps and make one." Page 533 534 HEY were just sitting down to dinner when Johnny came bursting in without even waiting for anyone to answer his knock. He promptly pulled up a chair and joined them at the table. "Hi, Ellie!" he called. "Bring on an extra plate. This is practically your last chance to have me honor your board." "Your money has come!" said Geniel, beaming. "Good for you!" "Yes, Ma'am." "And now you are leaving for school," added Christine. "No, Ma'am." "You're not!' Marva practically shouted. "Why not? I thought that you had been waiting for this most of your short adult life." "Take it easy, little one,' he countered. "So I have. But something else has come up." "There wasn't as much money in the estate as you had hoped?" Christine suggested quietly. "Wr
